stream_context.summary: Kaze implements and polishes a beach-side sandcastle/thwomp star objective ("Sandbump"), including hit detection, particle effects, and post-objective dialogue/state logic. Along the way he riffs on coding-style dogma (magic numbers vs enums/defines) in response to the "pirate software" takedown discourse, mentions recent pull requests (font + song), and brainstorms an overworld gag NPC: the defeated Goomba King fishing and complaining after his Bunny Brushwoods mission.
stream_context.significance_reason: A discrete star/mission is brought to a "done" state (Sandbump), plus concrete project-planning info (193 planned stars) and a clear design beat for an overworld NPC vignette (Goomba King post-defeat), alongside a candid coding-philosophy rant useful for character and process.

findings.summary: Kaze completes the "Sandbump" objective loop: clear the sandcastles, spawn a thwomp, and award Mario a star, calling the feature "done" after validating dialogue/state changes.
He needs to spawn/award a star without triggering a level exit, and runs into issues where the post-star exit prompt/choices (“leave/stay”) behave incorrectly before he gets the flow working.
He diagnoses hit detection issues as a parameter/height mismatch ("it was just the height was wrong"), then continues proofing the interaction until it behaves consistently.
He realizes he lacks a reusable helper for a behavior he needs (a general-purpose function) and decides he "definitely" should add one, calling it out as an oversight.

A large chunk of the stream is spent iterating on sand/dust particle presets: initial attempts look "absolutely horrendous" until he finds a missing flag, adjusts drag/velocity, and fixes a lifetime/physics multiplier (0.5) that dramatically improves the look.

Kaze frames the new star as acceptably "Odyssey"-like, but defends it as still in-bounds for Mario 64 by comparing it to how many original SM64 stars have even less content than the objective he just implemented.

He pushes back against rigid coding-rule culture (especially backlash against "magic numbers"), arguing that one-off values—particularly for visuals—are inherently arbitrary and shouldn’t require enums/defines unless reused.
He mentions recent external contributions landing as pull requests: Zell added a new font, and Sauraen added a new song; he says “F3 is looking pretty stacked this year.”
Kaze gives a concrete scope snapshot: ~193 stars are currently planned, but he expects the total to grow organically as they build out and play through the overworld.

He outlines an overworld continuity gag: after you beat the Goomba King mission in Bunny Brushwoods, the Goomba King appears on the beach fishing, still complaining about his minions and never actually catching any fish—"he's done being the king."

He brainstorms visual comedy for the Goomba King (baldness via a single hair strand; possibly snorkel/goggles but that feels like "a whole ass skit") and rejects ideas that make him look like he's “having a good time.”
Kaze says Sauraen made a pull request that was merged for a new song.

key_stories.title: Finishing the Sandbump star loop (sandcastles → thwomp → star)
key_stories.summary: Kaze brings a beach objective to completion, stitching together combat/interaction checks, star spawning, and the NPC state/dialogue changes that should follow success. The work illustrates how seemingly small SM64-style stars become a web of engine quirks, cutscene logic, and UX details.
key_stories.challenge: Make the objective reliably award a star (without unintended level exits) and ensure post-objective dialogue/state behaves correctly.
key_stories.process: He tests hit detection, fixes a height parameter, sets up star spawning and star ID, then hunts down why dialogue/cutscene triggers still fire incorrectly. He adds a timed “no talking” window (~10 seconds / 300 frames) to prevent accidental NPC interactions during/after the sequence and re-tests the text updates after completion.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze validates the intended behavior (objective completion leads to the correct dialogue/state) and declares “Sandbump is done.”

key_stories.title: Making sand/dust particles not look terrible
key_stories.summary: A visual polish task turns into a debugging session when Kaze discovers missing flags and questionable physics/lifetime behavior in his particle system. The iteration shows the trial-and-error nature of making convincing N64-era effects inside a custom engine/hack.
key_stories.challenge: The chosen sand/dust particle preset looks “horrible” and behaves unnaturally (directionality, size, fade-out).
key_stories.process: He swaps presets, adjusts color/opacity fades, diagnoses strong drag and a missing flag, removes random translation offset, and finds a physics/lifetime multiplier that improves motion and fade behavior. He then rebalances size and saturation to match the scene.
key_stories.outcome: Particles become “so much better,” and he identifies at least one parameter that would have implied a broader game-wide particle issue if left unchanged.

key_stories.title: Coding dogma backlash after the "pirate software" takedown
key_stories.summary: Kaze reacts to a broader community moment where a publicized code critique led to people policing "magic numbers" and other style rules. He uses his own workflow—especially for visual tuning—to argue for pragmatism over rigid compliance.
key_stories.challenge: External discourse pressures developers to follow blanket style rules (enums/defines everywhere) that can slow iteration and add noise.
key_stories.process: He explains his rule-of-thumb: defines/enums make sense when a value is reused or likely to change globally, but one-off visual constants are inherently arbitrary and better left inline. He contrasts this with workplaces enforcing exhaustive rules (e.g., jump tables) and suggests many rules are more about process than outcomes.
key_stories.outcome: The stream captures a clear personal philosophy: optimize for iteration speed and maintainability where it matters, not performative cleanliness.
key_stories.key_quote: You shouldn't be so rigid in them.

open_questions.topic: How stars are awarded without forcing a level exit (and how that differs across contexts)
open_questions.context: Kaze explicitly needs to spawn a star without level exits and encounters buggy/blocked exit prompts and dialogue/cutscene triggers before getting the flow stable.
questions: In your engine/hack, what are the different “types” of star awards (exit star, non-exit star, cutscene star), and what makes each one fragile?
What actually caused the leave/stay prompt and dialogue logic to break here—was it a star-spawn flag, a cutscene state, or something more systemic?
Is “non-exit star awarding” a design pillar for Return to Yoshi’s Island (more overworld-style play), or just a case-by-case tool?

open_questions.topic: Scope planning: 193 planned stars and how new stars get added
open_questions.context: Kaze says 193 stars are planned but expects the count to rise as they build/play through the overworld.
questions: Where did the 193 planned stars number come from—was it a spreadsheet, course-by-course design targets, or a narrative/overworld structure?
What’s your bar for adding “random more stars” during development—does it happen when a space feels empty, when a mechanic emerges, or when testers get stuck/bored?
How do you prevent late-added stars from ballooning scope or breaking pacing across the full game?

open_questions.topic: Overworld continuity NPCs (Goomba King after Bunny Brushwoods)
open_questions.context: Kaze wants the Goomba King to appear fishing on the beach after his mission, as a character beat that extends beyond a single course and rewards completion with worldbuilding.
questions: How important is it to you that bosses/NPCs “live” in the overworld after you beat them, versus disappearing like traditional SM64?
What’s the tone target for these vignettes—pure comedy, quiet character moments, or hints at a larger story?
Do you envision the Goomba King’s fishing as a purely cosmetic gag, or will you later turn it into a star/minigame without undermining the joke that he never catches anything?
